statements.statement: In my experience, consent forms contain too much information
In my experience, consent forms are easy to understand
Consent forms never confuse me
In my experience, consent forms are too vague to make sense
I often feel pressured into signing consent forms
I have nothing to hide, so I don’t worry about sharing my data
I don’t really care about my data
I always read consent forms
I do not want to be annoyed by consent forms because I want to get on with using the service
I don’t trust any online services – and that includes what they say they will do with my data
Consent forms should be simple
If consent forms should include both text and pictures so that I can understand them better
A consent form on its own is insufficient. I would like to log in to see what a company is doing with my data
I would like a minimal form with more information on request
If service providers behave ethically, consent forms should only contain essential information
Consent forms just exist to prevent people from exercising their rights
Consent forms are a hurdle to be navigated
Consent forms are informative
Sometimes consent forms look like back-covering exercises
Consent forms are focused on my needs
Before signing a consent form I find the advice useful that a security professional has checked that the service provider stores and uses my data lawfully
The advice that ethical hackers have tested the service provider’s system, and were not able to break into it, reassures me before signing a consent form
I find it helpful to be told, before signing a consent form, the percentage of users that are happy with the way the service provider stores and uses their data
I am reassured when a consent form gives examples to make it clearer how the forms apply to me
I would like to ask questions before signing the form to reassure me
